turn.label: Mr. Cornish F. Hitchcock
turn.text: It... it would depend at what level it was being served.
If you had the kind of--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: At the level that produces the same risk that you're concerned about from tobacco.

turn.speaker: cornish_f_hitchcock
turn.label: Mr. Cornish F. Hitchcock
turn.text: --If... yes.
If you had a level, a risk of 1 in 1,000, which is the risk of death by lung cancer or heart disease, my answer would be yes.

And to put that in context, 1 in 1,000 doesn't sound like much, but it is a level which this Court, in the benzene case, said entitles OSHA to regulate risks on the grounds that they are significant, and OSHA has, in fact, regulated product... exposure in the workplace to products such as formaldehyde or ethylene oxide.
And it is well above the tolerance level that EPA and the FDA use in their own regulation of other cancerous materials.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But you really don't contend that OSHA standards apply in prison, do you?

turn.speaker: cornish_f_hitchcock
turn.label: Mr. Cornish F. Hitchcock
turn.text: Well, OSHA standards do not apply in prison, but in terms of... of the risk that they would--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Or even they... it wouldn't have to have even the same degree, or do you think that there should be the same degree of risk in--

turn.speaker: cornish_f_hitchcock
turn.label: Mr. Cornish F. Hitchcock
turn.text: --Well, there... there's at least one case I'm aware of, Justice Stevens, a court of appeals decision which involved exposure to pesticides.

And it was held that there was cruel... there was an Eight Amendment violation stated if prison inmates were out working in the fields under... with exposure to pesticides that was not comparable to those of private employees with the same standard.

So it... it may be, but in this case if we're comparing risks and comparing... I'm putting it in context... EPA and FDA will regulate risks if the chance of death from lung cancer is as low as 1 in 100,000 or 1 in a million.
Also, the other serious injury, you know, which again has not been identified with child abuse, is death by lung cancer.
The Journal of the American Medical Association has indicated that the chance of death is as high as 1 in 100, based on exposure to cigarette smoke among people who never smoke.
If the Court has no further questions, we ask the charge be affirmed.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: --Thank you, Mr. Hitchcock.
General Del Papa, you have a minute remaining.

section.heading: Rebuttal of Frankie Sue Del Papa

turn.speaker: frankie_sue_del_papa
turn.label: Mr. Frankie Sue Del Papa
turn.text: Justice White, in response to your question to Mr. Roberts, we did note in our petition that the Ninth Circuit erred in the way that it framed the issue at pages 25-29 of our--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Thank you very much.

turn.speaker: frankie_sue_del_papa
turn.label: Mr. Frankie Sue Del Papa
turn.text: --I have just a couple of brief points.
We alerted the Court to our policy and the fact that it had changed, not that it was written, in our reply brief at the petition stage.
We would contend--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, why didn't you tell the Ninth Circuit about this?

turn.speaker: frankie_sue_del_papa
turn.label: Mr. Frankie Sue Del Papa
turn.text: --I don't believe there was an opportunity.
And, again, we would contend--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But the policy change was in 1989, wasn't it?

turn.speaker: frankie_sue_del_papa
turn.label: Mr. Frankie Sue Del Papa
turn.text: --But it was... I think, due to the timing and the way the... the policy actually, Your Honor, came out before the magistrate actually... the policy came out before trial.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But it was inconsistent with the stipulation.

turn.speaker: frankie_sue_del_papa
turn.label: Mr. Frankie Sue Del Papa
turn.text: We're contending that the... that the policy has not materially changed, particularly with... with reference to the accommodations.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But, you must agree, I think, that the written policy is inconsistent with certain parts of the stipulation.

turn.speaker: frankie_sue_del_papa
turn.label: Mr. Frankie Sue Del Papa
turn.text: I don't agree with that.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You don't agree.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Thank you, General Del Papa.
The case is submitted.
